intro: Picris xylopoda, commonly known as the common goldenweed, is a herbaceous plant native to Europe, North Africa, and parts of Asia. It typically grows in disturbed soils and along roadsides, reaching heights of up to 60 centimeters. The plant features alternate, lance-shaped leaves with hairy surfaces, and its flowers are small, yellow, and clustered in loose inflorescences. It blooms from late spring to early autumn, producing numerous seeds that are dispersed by wind. Botanically, it belongs to the Asteraceae family, which is characterized by its composite flower heads and medicinal properties in some species.
